urn:contentItem:6GHP-3F23-RS2D-B09V-00000-00Not anti-renewables but anti rip-off2025-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisNot anti-renewables but anti rip-offRoz Foyer

The was a hoolie blowing through the highlands last week.

The Community Council Renewable Convention, a collective meeting held in Inverness last week, brought together 53 community councils across the region to discuss their concerns over the impact of renewable energy developments.

Hell hath no fury like a scorned community council and rightly so. Pulling together a meeting that represents over 80,000 residents is no mean feat. Logistically impressive but, more to the point, very politically astute. The outcome was a document - a declaration of Inverness, if you will - signed by local and national politicians to back -urgent debates- over the speed, scale and outcomes of renewable projects within the area.

The Convention touched on people-s real anger and feeling of being completely scunnered with renewable projects popping up over their region and there being no immediate community benefit. They are, of course, correct.

Read More:

If Labour and SNP won-t push for change, populists will Scotland needs a radical approach to tackle attainment gap Scotland needs more workers - here's how we attract them Reform is the symptom and not the cause of problems

In our submission to the Scottish Government-s consultation Offshore Wind Policy Statement, the STUC has made clear that communities up and down the land are being short-changed and given the short shrift by multinational corporations who reap the profits of the resources communities provide them.

Further to the point, it's also not the -just transition- Scotland was promised. It-s a system where our natural resources generate massive wealth for private companies, with a trickle of jobs and community benefit in return and even then, those jobs are laced with precarity and insecure conditions.

For example, developers are meant to provide Community Benefit Funds, with the Scottish Government recommending a baseline of 5,000 per megawatt. But in practice, many projects fall short and these funds pale in comparison to what community ownership can deliver.

Contrast two wind projects in Argyll & Bute: Beinn an Tuirc, owned by Scottish Power Renewables, returns about 2,500 per megawatt to the community whilst Tilley, a single turbine owned by the Tiree Community Development Trust, returns over 263,000 per megawatt.

That difference is transformative. That-s true community wealth building. Yet in 2024, less than 1% of new renewable capacity in Scotland was under local or community ownership.

When ministers first marketed Scotland as the -Saudi Arabia of renewables-, it was sold as the prize for embracing the low carbon transition, with an alleged wave of well-paid, high-quality jobs spread across our communities, delivering both climate justice and economic renewal.

But if we strip away the spin and look at the hard data from the latest Office for National Statistics analysis of Scotland-s Low Carbon and Renewable Energy Economy, as the STUC has done in our new report, that prize has yet to arrive.

In fact, the growth we-ve seen is concentrated in a handful of areas and in the case of nuclear power, jobs are already disappearing. Meanwhile, the industries making the most money, onshore and offshore wind, continue to create relatively few jobs for the scale of their turnover, while far too much of the profit leaves Scotland entirely.

Between 2022 and 2023, total jobs in Scotland-s low carbon economy rose from 26,000 to 33,500, the highest level since ONS began collecting this data in 2014. That-s a headline ministers will happily boast about. But let-s look at the detail.

Most of those new jobs came in sectors like low-emission vehicles and infrastructure, energy-efficient lighting and energy-efficient products.

By contrast, the offshore and onshore wind industries, which dominate the Scottish Government-s green industrial strategy, saw jobs barely move. Offshore wind added just 100 jobs in a year. Onshore wind added 200. Combined, they now account for just over 6,800 jobs, or about 20% of all low carbon employment, despite generating more than half of all turnover and exports in the sector.

Put bluntly, for every million pounds of turnover, offshore wind creates just 1.3 jobs; onshore wind creates less than one. Compare that to low-emission vehicle manufacturing at over 21 jobs per million, or energy-efficient lighting at almost 19.

The root problem is simple: Scotland still lacks a serious, joined-up green industrial strategy that links climate targets to secure, skilled, unionised jobs.

Too much of our policy has been designed to maximise deployment of renewable energy without securing the domestic manufacturing base needed to turn that investment into lasting employment. As of 2024, Scotland has 12.4GW of installed onshore and offshore wind, compared to just 7.5GW in Denmark. Yet the Danes show what-s possible when you do this right: they-ve captured 40% of the European wind market.

Our report shows Scotland would need 19 major manufacturing sites for nacelles, blades, towers and more to fully capture the economic opportunity from ScotWind. So far, only two cable manufacturing sites have been announced. Without that domestic production capacity, developers will continue importing vast amounts of equipment and the jobs will stay overseas.

Even when these huge projects come online, the picture gets even more skewed. Take Seagreen, now the world-s sixth-largest offshore wind farm. In its first year of operation, it generated 449 million in revenue and produced a profit of 127 million. The entire operations and maintenance centre employs just 80 people. As new wind farms become operational and begin to generate electricity and therefore income for the developer, their spending falls dramatically, including for labour.

Therein lies the palpable frustration felt by many local residents. They-re not anti-renewables, per se. They-re anti-rip off and want to see a real community benefit to the inevitable disruption that comes with large scale renewable projects.

The Scottish Government-s 2024 Green Industrial Strategy names wind as a -priority area- but fails to address the real barriers: lack of manufacturing capacity, lack of community benefit, lack of job creation proportional to turnover. Even worse, it barely mentions the energy-efficiency sectors that already employ more than a third of all workers in the low carbon economy.

The solution is apparent: the Scottish Government must reform their approach to the development of offshore wind if there is to be any meaningful and last economic footprint from these natural resources. That includes setting Fair Work and Just Transition conditions across leasing, planning applications and public investment projects. This can be achieved, in part, through negotiations between trade unions and wind industry representatives and finally giving unions a seat at the table of the Scottish Offshore Wind Energy Council (SOWEC).

Secondly, we need to put communities at the heart of our national strategy, building greater public ownership of energy at a local level including with binding targets for community and local authority ownership of renewables.

Lastly supporting reform of employment law to establish universal standards and minimum wage floors in the energy sector and clearer structures for collective bargaining.

As the trade unionist Jimmy Reid once said, the untapped resources of Scotland-s North Sea are as nothing compared to the untapped resources of our people.

The answer isn-t blowing in the wind, it's lying in our communities.

Roz Foyer is the general secretary of the STUC

urn:contentItem:6GHP-8983-S5TM-D46J-00000-00Not anti-renewables but anti rip-off2025-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisPg. 15Not anti-renewables but anti rip-offF L-Mark Smith

THERE was a hoolie blowing through the Highlands last week.

The Community Council Renewable Convention, a collective meeting held in Inverness last week, brought together 53 community councils across the region to discuss their concerns over the impact of renewable energy developments.

Hell hath no fury like a scorned community council, and rightly so. Pulling together a meeting that represents over 80,000 residents is no mean feat. Logistically impressive but, more to the point, very politically astute. The outcome was a document - a declaration of Inverness, if you will - signed by local and national politicians to back "urgent debates" over the speed, scale and outcomes of renewable projects within the area.

The Convention touched on people's real anger and feeling of being completely scunnered with renewable projects popping up over their region and there being no immediate community benefit. They are, of course, correct.

In our submission to the Scottish Government's consultation Offshore Wind Policy Statement, the STUC has made clear that communities up and down the land are being short-changed and given the short shrift by multinational corporations who reap the profits of the resources communities provide them.

Further to the point, it's also not the "just transition" Scotland was promised. It's a system where our natural resources generate massive wealth for private companies, with a trickle of jobs and community benefit in return and even then, those jobs are laced with precarity and insecure conditions.

For example, developers are meant to provide Community Benefit Funds, with the Scottish Government recommending a baseline of £5,000 per megawatt. But in practice, many projects fall short and these funds pale in comparison to what community ownership can deliver.

Contrast two wind projects in Argyll & Bute: Beinn an Tuirc, owned by Scottish Power Renewables, returns about £2,500 per megawatt to the community whilst Tilley, a single turbine owned by the Tiree Community Development Trust, returns over £263,000 per megawatt.

That difference is transformative. That's true community wealth building. Yet in 2024, less than 1% of new renewable capacity in Scotland was under local or community ownership.

When ministers first marketed Scotland as the "Saudi Arabia of renewables", it was sold as the prize for embracing the low carbon transition, with an alleged wave of well-paid, high-quality jobs spread across our communities, delivering both climate justice and economic renewal.

But if we strip away the spin and look at the hard data from the latest Office for National Statistics analysis of Scotland's Low Carbon and Renewable Energy Economy, as the STUC has done in our new report, that prize has yet to arrive.

In fact, the growth we've seen is concentrated in a handful of areas and in the case of nuclear power, jobs are already disappearing. Meanwhile, the industries making the most money, onshore and offshore wind, continue to create relatively few jobs for the scale of their turnover, while far too much of the profit leaves Scotland entirely.

Between 2022 and 2023, total jobs in Scotland's low carbon economy rose from 26,000 to 33,500, the highest level since ONS began collecting this data in 2014. That's a headline ministers will happily boast about. But let's look at the detail.

Most of those new jobs came in sectors such as low-emission vehicles and infrastructure, energy-efficient lighting and energy-efficient products.

By contrast, the offshore and onshore wind industries, which dominate the Scottish Government's green industrial strategy, saw jobs barely move. Offshore wind added just 100 jobs in a year. Onshore wind added 200.Combined, they now account for just over 6,800 jobs, or about 20% of all low carbon employment, despite generating more than half of all turnover and exports in the sector.

Put bluntly, for every million pounds of turnover, offshore wind creates just 1.3 jobs; onshore wind creates less than one.Compare that to low-emission vehicle manufacturing at over 21 jobs per million, or energy-efficient lighting at almost 19.

The root problem is simple: Scotland still lacks a serious, joined-up green industrial strategy that links climate targets to secure, skilled, unionised jobs.

Too much of our policy has been designed to maximise deployment of renewable energy without securing the domestic manufacturing base needed to turn that investment into lasting employment. As of 2024, Scotland has 12.4GW of installed onshore and offshore wind, compared to just 7.5GW in Denmark. Yet the Danes show what's possible when you do this right: they've captured 40% of the European wind market.

Our report shows Scotland would need 19 major manufacturing sites for nacelles, blades, towers and more to fully capture the economic opportunity from ScotWind. So far, only two cable manufacturing sites have been announced. Without that domestic production capacity, developers will continue importing vast amounts of equipment and the jobs will stay overseas.

Even when these huge projects come online, the picture gets even more skewed. Take Seagreen, now the world's sixth-largest offshore wind farm. In its first year of operation, it generated £449 million in revenue and produced a profit of £127m. The entire operations and maintenance centre employs just 80 people. As new wind farms become operational and begin to generate electricity and therefore income for the developer, their spending falls dramatically, including for labour.

Therein lies the palpable frustration felt by many local residents. They're not anti-renewables, per se. They're anti-rip off and want to see a real community benefit to the inevitable disruption that comes with large scale renewable projects.

The Scottish Government's 2024 Green Industrial Strategy names wind as a "priority area" but fails to address the real barriers: lack of manufacturing capacity, lack of community benefit, lack of job creation proportional to turnover. Even worse, it barely mentions the energy-efficiency sectors that already employ more than a third of all workers in the low carbon economy.

The solution is apparent: the Scottish Government must reform their approach to the development of offshore wind if there is to be any meaningful and last economic footprint from these natural resources. That includes setting Fair Work and Just Transition conditions across leasing, planning applications and public investment projects. This can be achieved, in part, through negotiations between trade unions and wind industry representatives and finally giving unions a seat at the table of the Scottish Offshore Wind Energy Council (SOWEC).

Secondly, we need to put communities at the heart of our national strategy, building greater public ownership of energy at a local level including with binding targets for community and local authority ownership of renewables.

Lastly, supporting reform of employment law to establish universal standards and minimum wage floors in the energy sector and clearer structures for collective bargaining.

As the trade unionist Jimmy Reid once said, the untapped resources of Scotland's North Sea are as nothing compared to the untapped resources of our people.

The answer isn't blowing in the wind, it's lying in our communities.

Roz Foyer is the general secretary of the STUC

urn:contentItem:6GBW-92P3-RSF2-00G0-00000-00No warm welcome for Donald Trump at Aberdeen protest2025-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisNEWSNo warm welcome for Donald Trump at Aberdeen protest

Protesters gathered in Aberdeen ahead of Donald Trump’s visit to his North East golf course.

There was no warm welcome for Donald Trump to be found in Aberdeen city centre as hundreds gathered to oppose the visit of the US President.

Union Terrace was decorated with flags and placards, some written in the spirit of the late Janey Godley and her infamous sign, as the Stop Trump Coalition protest got underway.

One woman, from Newport-on-Tay, waved her Donald Trump toilet brush in defiance of the President of the United States and his arrival in Scotland.

Pam Lowe, 77, said: “My father came from Poland, now Ukraine and what Donald Trump has done , and particularly his interview with Zelensky, well I am disgusted with him.

“That is why I felt I had to come today. The toilet brush is actually used in my bathroom - and I have great fun using it.”

A large array of interests and groups were represented at the protest, including speeches from trade unions, climate justice campaigners and those deeply opposed to the war in Gaza taking to the stage. It was these speeches that roused the strongest reaction amongst the crowds as Palestinian colours flew high.

READ MORE: In pictures: Protests in Edinburgh against Donald Trump’s visit

Mostly, people said they wanted their opposition to Trump’s visit, when he is due to meet Prime Minister Keir Starmer and First Minister John Swinney in the North East, to be seen.

Craig Donald, 35, from Aberdeen, said: “I came as I wanted to register my disapproval of Trump's visit to Scotland. Donald Trump is a racist, he is a misogynist and he is wanting to turn back the clock on issues like abortion, for example.

READ MORE: Live Blog: Donald Trump in Scotland

“Today, he made a speech that Europe is being overrun by immigrants. I want to register my disapproval of everything he stands for and I don’t think he should be coming and, quite frankly, it is a disgrace that we are having to pay for his security.”

Mr Donald brought a sign urging the ‘Mango Mussolini to Ging Awa’, which was made after a ‘couple of drinks’ on Friday night.

READ MORE: First Minister announces £180,000 for golf competition at Trump’s Aberdeenshire golf course

He added: “Ultimately, it is a shame we have to come here to protest against this man coming, but we wanted to inject a bit of humour into it as well . We put a bit of Doric in there. I am just glad there are so many people here to oppose Donald Trump being in Scotland.”

READ MORE: Everything you need to know about Donald Trump’s visit to Scotland

Gabrielle Reith, 48, from Aberdeen, held up her sign - ‘Donald Yer a Loser- during the speeches.

She said: “Donald Trump stands for everything that I don’t. He is part of what is wrong with the world and the billionaires that are stripping everything from us - all the resources, all the human rights - that we should have.

“He is destroying the climate, he has destroyed part of the natural environment in Aberdeenshire.

“I felt very strongly about the golf course at Menie . He destroyed a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) and took away the rights of the people who lived there.

“If you don’t speak out you are part of the silent majority, the people who don’t come to protests but still have opinions. I was brought up to believe that protest was important.”

READ MORE: Sign up to The Scotsman’s politics newsletter for the best insight and analysis from the corridors of power

Maggie Chapman, Green MSP for North East Scotland, opened speeches.

She said : “I think it really important to stand in solidarity with Aberdeen and the rest of Scotland today to say that Trump is not welcome here - and neither are his politics.”

urn:contentItem:6G6Y-FTW3-RY2P-52J7-00000-00Hyrdo's new meatless menu for big shows2025-07-08T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisPg. 3Hyrdo's new meatless menu for big shows

THE HYDRO has announced a massive shake-up to their menu as all food will be plant-based for some huge shows.

Ahead of sold-out shows this week, the venue announced a change to its food offerings, featuring a meatless menu.

They've said they're 'Going Green for Billie' ahead of American superstar Billie Eilish's gigs at the clydeside arena last night and tonight.

Playfully titled options on the menu utilise the award-winning, chart-topping singer's back catalogue of songs to inspire the names of each dish.

Announcing the change on social media, the Hydro said: "We are excited to announce that for both Billie Eilish shows at the OVO Hydro (7 and 8 July), we will be offering all plant-based hot food across all retail units."

The menu features the 'Bad Guy Burger - a Beetroot and bean burger... duh!', the 'Birds of a Feather - Shittake burger on a soft bun', and the 'You Should See me in a Crown - Classic Quorn burger'.

They have a range of pizzas too, including the 'What Was I Wlade For? - Margherite pizza with plant-based cheese', the 'No Time to Die - Plant-based meatball marinara pizza' and the 'Lovely Pizza. - Vibrant and colourful roasted pepper pizza'.

And for those looking for a lighter bite, they also have the 'Ocean Eyes - Cheese and curry sauce fries', the 'Bury a Friend - Our signature home-made plain fries' and the 'All the Good Guys Go to Hell - Spiced BBQ fries'.

The Birds of a Feather singer has been on her world tour since September last year and doors opened in Glasgow at 6pm last night.

Ecstatic fans piled into tents inside the red pedestrian walkway bridge over the Clydeside Expressway on Sunday evening and into the early hours of Monday morning.

The dedicated 'Eyelashers' were lining up in the hopes of getting to the front of the sold-out crowd.

Billie Eilish hopes to make the tour as sustainable as possible and will continue her long-standing partnership with environmental nonprofit REVERB.

This previously resulted in over £790,000 being donated to greenhouse gas reduction, and climate justice projects.

The tour will also work to reduce single-use plastic waste, supporting climate action, and updating concession offerings to promote and encourage plant-based food options with Support+Feed.

Fans are encouraged to join the effort to make the tour more sustainable.

Where possible, take public transportation and carpool to and from the shows to help reduce pollution and encourage more public transportation options.

In addition to efforts to decrease waste through reducing or eliminating single-use plastics and diverting landfill waste with compost and recycling, venues will be offering plant-based food options at all shows.

urn:contentItem:6DDX-8GK1-JBSW-32K4-00000-00Climate campaigners gather in Bradford for Global Day of Action for Climate Justice2024-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisClimate campaigners gather in Bradford for Global Day of Action for Climate JusticeFelicity Macnamara

MEMBERS of Fossil Free West Yorkshire and Global Justice gathered in Bradford on Friday.

It was part of the Global Day of Action for Climate Justice.

They gathered in front of the West Yorkshire Pension Fund-s (WYPF) offices in Aldermanbury House.

Jane Thewlis, from Fossil Free West Yorkshire, said: -What faces us, as we can see when we look at the videos of Catalonia in Spain, is like a horror film or sci-fi.

-But this is real and predicted to get worse. Climate breakdown won-t benefit any of us.-

Campaigners want to see the WYPF, which is administered by Bradford Council, divest from fossil fuel companies, though Ms Thewlis said they-re -delighted- West Yorkshire is leading the way.

Earlier this year, the WYPF said: -To reinforce our commitment to increased investment in climate solutions, WYPF wishes to make clear that it will not use WYPF assets to fund new fossil fuel developments.

-In particular, WYPF will not be lending to the oil, gas and coal sector and will continue to work with other like-minded investors to demand a similar approach from the banking industry.-

WYPF said it would also review its level of equity holdings in the oil and gas sector.

Newly-elected Labour MPs Paul Davies (Colne Valley) and Anna Dixon (Shipley) have joined 12 other West Yorkshire MPs in the call for WYPF to divest from fossil fuels.

urn:contentItem:6GBC-9WD3-RSXR-V3XW-00000-00ICJ rules countries legally obligated to tackle climate change2025-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisICJ rules countries legally obligated to tackle climate change

The world's highest courton Wednesday declared that states have a legal obligation to tackle climate change and that failing to do so was a "wrongful act" that could open the door to reparations.

The decision by the International Court of Justice was closely watched by legal experts, who said the judges' opinion could mark a turning point for environmental justice and climate litigation around the world.

ICJ advisory opinions are not binding but carry considerable moral and legal weight, and Wednesday's decision was seen as the most consequential in a recent string of landmark climate rulings.

The United Nations had tasked the 15 judges at the ICJ, a UN court in the Hague that adjudicates disputes between nations, to answer two fundamental questions.

First: what must states do under international law to protect the environment from greenhouse gas emissions "for present and future generations"?

Second: what are the consequences for states whose emissions have caused environmental harm, especially to vulnerable low-lying island states?

In handing down the decision, ICJ president Yuji Iwasawa said climate change was an "urgent and existential threat" and states breaching their obligations to address the crisis were committing "an internationally wrongful act".

"The legal consequences resulting from the commission of an internationally wrongful act may include... full reparations to injured states in the form of restitution, compensation and satisfaction," the court said.

This would be on a case-by-case basis where a "sufficient direct and certain causal nexus" had been shown "between the wrongful act and the injury", it added.

It also said the climate "must be protected for present and future generations" and the adverse effect of a warming planet "may significantly impair the enjoyment of certain human rights, including the right to life".

Experts said it would take time to go over the full advisory opinion, which is the biggest case ever handled by the ICJ.

To reach its decision, ICJ judges pored over tens of thousands of pages of submissions from countries and organisations around the world.

'No more delay'

Outside the court in the Hague, about a hundred demonstrators waved flags and posters bearing slogans like "No more delay, climate justice today".

Courts have become a key battleground for climate action as frustration has grown over sluggish progress toward curbing planet-warming pollution from fossil fuels.

The Paris Agreement struck through the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) has rallied a global response to the crisis, but not at the speed necessary to protect the world from dangerous overheating.

The journey to the world's highest court was six years in the making, spearheaded by students from the climate-imperilled Pacific region, and championed by tiny island nation Vanuatu.

Ahead of the ruling, Vanuatu's climate change minister Ralph Regenvanu said the advisory opinion could be a "game-changer".

"We've been going through this for 30 years. It'll shift the narrative, which is what we need to have," Regenvanu told AFP.

More than 100 nations and groups gave submissions at a mammoth hearing in December in the Great Hall of Justice in the Hague.

Many hailed from distant Pacific Island nations, and delivered impassioned appeals in the sober arena dressed in colourful traditional attire.

The debate pitted major wealthy economies against the smaller, less developed states most at the mercy of a warming planet.

Big pollutersincluding the United States and India argued that legal provisions under the UNFCCC were sufficient and a re-examination of state responsibility in relation to climate action was not necessary.

But smaller states refuted this, saying the UN framework was inadequate to mitigate climate change's devastating effects and that the ICJ's opinion should be broader.

These states also urged the ICJ to impose reparations on historic polluters, a highly sensitive issue in global climate negotiations.

They also demanded a commitment and timeline to phasing out fossil fuels, monetary compensation when appropriate, and an acknowledgement of past wrongs.

Ahead of the decision, experts said the advisory opinion could have ripple effects across national courts, legal processes, and public debate.

Abstract

Cities are increasingly pursuing sustainability efforts to create inclusive, safe, and climate resilient places. However, there is evidence that emerging climate adaptation actions in cities—whether intentionally or unintentionally—are contributing to widening socioeconomic inequalities. Scholars of climate urbanism have responded to this challenge by calling for efforts to tackle underlying injustices. Leveraging such insights, we provide an empirical assessment of 25 U.S. cities’ plans to address distributional inequities through climate adaptation. Despite increasing scholarly attention, we find that, in practice, cities have relatively limited, but growing, engagements with distributive equity in their adaptation efforts. We find evidence that distributive strategies tend to coalesce across five key sectors: economic empowerment, food and health, housing and land use, urban greening, and water. We find that a focus on distributive climate justice—as complementary to existing research on procedural equity—is needed to advance broader, more comprehensive climate justice goals in cities.

Introduction

Cities are important arenas for mobilizing climate justice, particularly in the U.S. context where the federal government has frequently abdicated such responsibility to states and local governments. From 2021 through 2024, the U.S. federal government under President Biden’s Administration advocated for a whole-of-government approach to climate action. This leadership provided an opportunity to rethink urban climate justice given the new flow of federal dollars from the Inflation Reduction Act (2022) and Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (2022), through federal efforts such as the Environmental and Climate Justice Community Change Grants program and Carbon Pollution Reduction Grants program from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Department of Housing and Urban Development’s Resilience Hubs program, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s climate health equity work, and others. However, the reelection of former President Trump in November 2024 ushered in an administration openly hostile to efforts to further sustainability, climate action, and environmental justice, which has put more onus on frontline communities to address risks and adapt to uncertain climate impacts themselves.

Because many cities are already on the frontlines of extreme disaster impacts, there has been a lot of research on how cities can lead the way in reducing carbon emissions and other mitigation efforts (e.g.,1, 2–3). Adaptation is equally important as cities think through how to address risks in equitable and inclusive ways. Many of these efforts align with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) including SDG11 on sustainable cities and SD13 on climate action. However, even though some past federal efforts have focused on climate justice ideas (e.g., Executive Order 14008 in 2021), empirical examples are scarce with few illustrations of urban implementation.

Climate change will have differential impacts on communities, creating risks and exacerbating socioeconomic vulnerabilities. Climate justice research, which builds on environmental justice research, considers the importance of procedural, distributive, and recognitional equity and their linkages (e.g.,4, 5, 6, 7–8). Briefly, procedural equity refers to participation of residents, particularly those from marginalized communities. Distributive equity refers to the distribution of resources and services, while recognition refers to acknowledging and addressing specific concerns of those from marginalized communities (e.g.,9). Researchers of urban planning and climate adaptation have applied climate justice research to better understand how cities consider justice and equity in their decision-making10, 11–12. While most of the planning literature has focused on process, such as designing representative decision-making arrangements and public engagement/communication (mostly one-way) to advance procedural equity10,13, 14, 15–16, less attention has been paid to distributive equity actions.

Critical scholarship, such as that of climate urbanism (e.g.,17), call our attention to the necessity for considering distributional forms of justice that may lead to more just and equitable outcomes through adaptation planning. Scholars in this space have focused on the normative critiques of climate adaptation strategies that either exacerbate or maintain social inequality and climate vulnerability (e.g.,14,18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23–24).

This paper builds on such prior research by linking climate urbanism and climate justice research, specifically around what cities are doing to advance distributive equity in climate adaptation. Adaptation planning, which focuses on what actions cities are undertaking to prepare and respond to climate impacts, has been frequently understudied particularly in relation to climate mitigation, or strategies cities take to reduce drivers of climate change (e.g., greenhouse gas emissions)1, 2–3. While acknowledging procedural, distributive, and recognitional forms of equity are linked, here we focus on climate adaptation actions that seek to promote distributive equity given the dearth of research on what cities are trying to redistribute services to ameliorate inequalities their residents experience.

While climate urbanism offers a political economic diagnosis of the drivers of injustice across urban spaces, more nuanced interrogations of climate justice also suggests what can be done to rectify these inequalities. In bridging these literatures, we identify what cities are doing on the ground to advance equity, specifically around distributive efforts, through adaptation planning. We do this by examining the stand-alone adaptation planning documents—where cities lay out their intentions to promote climate action - available as of the end of 2024, for the 25 largest U.S. cities. While many studies in this area tend to focus on a single city at a time (e.g.,12,25,) or a handful of cities (e.g.,10,14,), we have sought a larger sample of cities to better understand which actions cities are coalescing around and to identify exemplars of planned actions that seek to promote distributive equity. Doing so advances climate urbanism scholarship and adaptation research by documenting the specific ways that cities are implementing efforts to address the distribution of inequalities, thereby supplementing concurrent research on the procedural dimensions—i.e., of inclusive, participatory, and community-driven approaches—of adaptation planning15. It may also support ways to advance and implement broader, more comprehensive climate justice goals—in response to SDGs 11 and 13 but also considering increasing federal policy uncertainties and hostilities towards both climate action and equity—in U.S. cities.

There is an abundance of research showing how urban planning has at times created and exacerbated social and environmental inequality through discriminatory land use, housing, public health, and environmental decision-making26,27. Sustainable urban development, as captured in SDG 11, is key for fighting both the impacts and inequities attributed to climate change. Cities encapsulate the equity challenge among U.S. society as they are microcosms of social, economic, and political injustice as seen through many decades of unequal development, planning, and extractive development, especially arranged along racial lines and class divides. However, cities are also important sites of trialing more innovative, progressive efforts to planning14. U.S. cities and suburbs are home to a large proportion of the U.S. population—~80%28—making them a center of climate adaptation funding, infrastructure intervention, and policy attention. Cities are also hotspots of climate risks given the concentration of critical and expensive infrastructure and concentrated exposure of frontline communities29. As such, U.S. cities remain an important site for investigation of adaptation efforts.

Emerging through an interrogation of core theories across the fields of urban geography, critical social sciences, and the human dimensions of climate change, the literature on climate urbanism focuses on the uneven distribution of climate mitigation and adaptation investments and resulting unequal experience of climate risks by frontline communities30. Climate action, as outlined in SDG 13, is a necessary collection of strategies to develop sustainable societies, generally, and cities, specifically. Across many contexts, recent investments to support climate change action has redirected resources into technological and low-carbon infrastructure to mitigate or adapt to climate change25,30, 31–32. Yet most of these investments enable neoliberal regimes of capital production and accumulation, reinforcing existing forms of social exclusion, including those based on race, gender, and class30,33, 34–35. The result of which is continued or widening socioeconomic inequalities as climate change impacts are increasingly felt. This literature seeks to engage with the larger capitalist market systems that promote extractive, revenue-driven services, which (re)produce climate risks and inequalities, in an attempt to transform urban places in ways that prioritize justice and redefine what urban services exist and who they should serve17,20,25,36. (Although these studies offer a compelling critique of climate adaptation efforts, what adaptation actions should look like on the ground to achieve equity remains relatively undefined.

Given such critiques of the shifting and emergent neoliberal drivers of climate adaption, researchers are increasingly investigating what plans are proposing that is constructively supporting more equitable approaches to adaptation11,19,21,22,37. Recent scholarship highlights how some adaptation planning strategies have resulted in climate risks for marginalized and vulnerable communities21,38, 39–40. In response to such calls, there has been an uptick in scholarship developing and implementing justice and equity criteria in these efforts (see refs. 10,11). For example, Amorim-Maia et al.37 find in their case study of Barcelona, Spain that city planners with community partners engaged different tactics - disruptive planning, working across city agencies, centering care in their planning approaches, and leveraging place-based strategies for the most vulnerable residents -to advance equity and justice in adaptation strategies. Brousseau et al.41 found in their study of 101 adaptation plans and related documents in the U.S. that more recent plans tended to engage with procedural, distributive, and recognitional justice more frequently than older plans, with communities experiencing poverty more likely to seek means of addressing distributive injustice.

Despite recent advances in urban climate justice research, we see two persistent gaps in knowledge. First, though many acknowledge procedural, distributive, and recognitional equity are linked (e.g.,11,41), most adaptation research has focused predominantly on assessing procedural equity and engagement with frontline communities through workshops, consultations, participatory forums, and stakeholder committees10,14,15. For example, Fitzgerald’s14 study of five climate action plans and the planners that developed them found that trust building is essential to increase procedural equity in adaptation planning. While procedural equity has been a focus of research, distributive equity has been comparatively less studied. Second, studies that have investigated questions of climate justice have tended to be theoretical (e.g.,30) or single case studies (e.g.,12,25). To fill this gap, our work assesses what multiple cities plan to do on the ground to advance distributive equity through adaptation planning.

In response to these two knowledge gaps, this paper identifies whether U.S. cities are addressing distributive equity in their adaptation planning through an analysis of local plans for the 25 largest U.S. cities. While climate urbanism offers a framework for diagnosing the drivers of urban inequality under climate change, it asserts that capitalist and speculative pathways that underline climate action leads to widening inequalities25,30. Climate justice is a framework that seeks to shed light on potential solutions to these problems of inequality. Our paper bridges these two fields by exploring how cities can focus on redistribution to tackle these drivers of inequality. To do this, we examine the kinds of strategies cities are employing in adaptation planning to address distributive equity, while identifying exemplars of what such action looks like on the ground.

Results

The results of our analysis of adaptation plans for the 25 largest U.S. cities for distributional equity are presented here. For more on the data and methods see the “Materials and Methods” section below.

Distributive outcomes in climate action and planning

Our analysis found that distributional equity strategies fall into five different categories—economic empowerment, food and health, housing and land use, urban greening, and water (see Table 1). Economic empowerment refers to strategies to boost residents’ capacities, particularly for frontline communities. Food and health refer to actions to improve food access and health outcomes. The housing and land use category includes strategies to increase housing stock, improve its accessibility, related anti-displacement measures, energy efficiency improvements, as well as efforts to retrofit buildings. Urban greening refers to actions to increase green space, such as tree canopy and green infrastructure. Finally, the water category includes strategies to distribute water. Each category is characterized by cities attempting to distribute goods, services, and programs to climate and socially vulnerable residents to address inequities they already experience. Several categories align with typical priority planning areas of a city, such as green space or housing, for which there is frequently dedicated programmatic staff. We additionally identified categories that were cross-cutting, where priorities spanned multiple sectors. Economic empowerment

Many cities—namely Los Angeles, Houston, Memphis, and Sacramento—include economic strategies for workforce development and job creation, particularly for climate vulnerable residents around other distributive outcomes such as through urban greening projects. For example, Houston aims to expand financial empowerment centers in under-resourced communities. As noted in the plan,

“In early 2020, the City in partnership with The Alliance [of neighborhood councils], opened three new financial empowerment centers in targeted Complete Communities [neighborhoods that have experienced historical disinvestment] that offer financial capability and financial literacy services to connect Houstonians to safe and affordable financial products and services to build savings and wealth” (p. 56).

This economic strategy provides both workforce development programs and financial literacy to help residents build wealth.

Workforce development programs for under-resourced communities frequently dovetailed with other areas of distributive equity such as those related to water, waste, and land use. For example, the Memphis plan seeks a 20% reduction in cardboard and paper waste in the waste stream and a 10% food waste reduction by 2030. It also included a workforce development plan related to waste reduction and circular economies for low-income communities. The plan further suggests an economic strategy of “encouraging circular economy opportunities for paper/cardboard and food waste will add jobs to the region, as well as stimulate local business partnerships to creatively use these materials” (p. 141).

The Los Angeles plan offers economic strategies that both seek to adapt the city to climate change and promote multiple distributive priorities. For example, the plan reads,

“In addition to the exciting projects around clean energy and urban greening, each project will incorporate workforce development plans that include training in a number of sectors—renewable energy technologies, low carbon transportation technologies, energy efficiency, waste diversion, healthy soils—and fight back against displacement” (p. 33).

Another example from the Los Angeles plan calls for 6500 jobs by 2025 supported by local solar installments. Finally, Sacramento plans to create workforce development around the electric vehicle (EV) infrastructure development to create living wage jobs for low-income residents (p. 27). Economic empowerment strategies such as these speak to the importance of transitioning the workforce to both reduce inequities and support the needs for climate action.

Food and health

An area of work that cities are undertaking to further distributive climate justice includes enhancing access to goods and services for underserved communities vulnerable to climate risks, including excessive heat, as well as those lacking access to healthy foods. Such strategies reduce inequities by helping residents secure basic needs and services to support capacity building and climate adaptation.

For example, Portland plans to have cooling centers in low-income and racial minority neighborhoods for the most vulnerable residents. Columbus plans to distribute goods and services—such as fans, air conditioners, and water—to vulnerable groups and to provide financial instruments to help people pay for sufficient cooling during the summer. The plan writes:

“Another reason to establish a network of cooling centers is that while a list of “formal” cooling centers can be provided to citizens, many residents might seek cooling in other “informal” locations such as retail centers, churches, libraries, and buses. There are ample opportunities for local businesses, faith communities, and community assets to participate in the cooling center network. Residents will turn to trusted locations, regardless of their identified status as “formal” cooling centers” (p. 19).

By establishing a network of trusted places—such as local businesses, churches, and libraries—to provide climate actions the city hopes more residents will find cooling places. Such efforts are essential for preventing adverse health outcomes, such as heat exhaustion and stroke, from extreme heat days. Such a network can help address the inequities arising from increases in excessive heat events due to climate change.

Dallas and Oklahoma City plan to increase access to healthy foods, in part, through urban agriculture, particularly in areas with limited access to food, while Kansas City plans to increase enrollment of minority farmers and ranchers into local programs to better represent the diversity of residents and farmers. By doing so, Kansas City seeks to scale up local food production to meet demands, while also reducing emissions from vehicle-miles-traveled that contribute to climate change in the first place by reducing miles that food must be transported. While Dallas seeks to reduce food waste by helping businesses transfer food that would otherwise go to waste. This strategy also seeks to reduce emissions from the food supply chain.

Housing and land use

Housing affordability and accessibility are other key areas of redistribution identified in the plans because of increased climate risks for the unhoused42. There remains a homelessness crisis across the U.S. (e.g.,43) with homeless residents experiencing some of the greatest climate vulnerability44. For example, San Antonio is the only plan in our sample that included anti-displacement measures, such as developing programs to help vulnerable groups have clear title to their home to try to keep people from marginalized communities in their homes and neighborhoods so they can also benefit from the adaptation measures being undertaken. The plan says,

“Develop measures to prevent displacement to ensure vulnerable groups, small businesses, and existing residents can stay in their homes/districts and benefit from resilience measures. Examples may include developing programs and policies to ensure low-income residents have clear title to their homes to allow for rebuilding as a result of weather-related damage or identifying energy-burdened households and providing resources to improve energy efficiency and increase thermal health” (p. 48).

Houston identified how housing segregation created differential risks to climate change hazards, such as flooding, for historically marginalized communities. Because of this, Houston plans to explore and pilot a voluntary relocation program for people and families that meet criteria, such as low or moderate income, severe flooding, and location in the floodplain, to new or refurbished homes with lower flood risk and within the same community. Finally, Denver was the only plan reviewed that included a program—the Denver Road Home Program (DRH)—to provide permanent housing, shelters, and services to the homeless population by building new homes and shelters, providing rental assistance to prevent evictions, and social support. The plan elaborates on this program’s successes:

“After year eight DRH added 2795 housing opportunities, generated 6702 employment and training opportunities, prevented 6199 families and individuals from becoming homeless through eviction prevention assistance, mentored 1208 families and seniors out of homelessness, housed 2275 individuals, and leveraged over $63 million in public and private dollars to help people” (p. 21).

Adaptation actions in this sector also include energy assistance for low-income housing and building retrofits in frontline communities. These initiatives seek to reduce impacts from climate change for those who are unequally burdened by it and/or lack adequate resources or data to access effective adaptation actions. For instance, Dallas has pursued low-cost weatherization through the Dallas County Health and Human Services’ Weatherization Assistance Program. The Dallas plan notes, “In partnership with Dallas County, the city will implement a weatherization program for the city’s vulnerable residents to improve energy efficiency and reduce utility costs” (p. 37). Similarly, Indianapolis has an Income-Qualified Weatherization Program and increased financial incentives for renewable energy, first to under-invested and historically marginalized neighborhoods. Another common approach is to address inequities by retrofitting buildings in frontline and under-resourced communities to make them more energy efficient (e.g., as seen in Memphis, Portland, San Francisco, San Antonio).

Waste management is another form of land use planning that cities are working in to advance distributive equity. For example, Los Angeles and Memphis both acknowledge that landfills tend to occur in low-income and communities of color. By reducing waste, it will decrease the emissions and impacts of these landfills. The Memphis plan notes, “reducing waste from these sectors can help decrease the need for new and/or enlarged landfills which often disproportionately impact low-income communities” (p. 140). Similarly, several cities—including Los Angeles, Memphis, and Portland—note the importance of reducing landfill emissions to reduce their contribution to climate change. Portland aims to do this through the “Be Cart Smart” campaign to raise awareness of recycling and composting programs. This program includes communication strategies for residents with limited English proficiency as well as to renters and landlords. Taken together, housing and land use is one established area where cities are working to adapt to climate change and address urban inequalities.

Urban greening

Infrastructure initiatives include expanding the urban tree canopy, particularly in communities that have experienced disinvestment, and green infrastructure to help alleviate climate impacts they are likely to face. One common strategy employed by cities such as Los Angeles, Sacramento, San Antonio, and Washington D.C. to address inequities—such as the urban heat island effect in predominantly poor and community of color neighborhoods (e.g.,45,46)—is by more evenly developing the urban tree canopy, which can reduce urban-heat island effects and provide shade. Los Angeles aims to increase the tree canopy in areas of greatest need by at least 50% by 2028 to provide cooling, habitat, and energy savings.

Similarly, Phoenix, Portland, San Francisco, and Washington D.C. seek to increase their tree canopy in similarly under-resourced communities for the same kinds of benefits. For example, Phoenix’s program is called “Right Tree, Right Place” to ensure drought tolerant trees are planted in places where they can grow. This effort also included training for city staff to ensure trees are properly cared for. The San Francisco plan focuses on the co-benefits of increasing the urban tree canopy with climate adapted plants. The plan notes,

“Tree planting will prioritize neighborhoods with low tree canopy rates, those most vulnerable to extreme heat, and public health/air quality disparities. Species will be selected with a climate adaptation and mitigation focus to promote carbon sequestration, pest and disease resilience, drought tolerance, urban heat island reduction, and stormwater filtration” (p.250).

From these examples, we see how cities are using urban greening strategies, including enhancing tree canopy, to provide climate co-benefits to mitigate climate impacts while trying to address urban inequalities.

Water

Water usage is another emergent category of distributive equity in adaptation planning as cities work to provide basic services to alleviate climate risks for vulnerable residents. A few cities plan to distribute water to those in need particularly during excessive heat days. For example, Phoenix assists partners in the Heat Relief Network—a regional partnership between the county association of governments, local municipalities, and non-profit organizations that emerged in response to a 2005 heatwave—to provide hydration stations and water-donation sites, while Columbus plans to distribute water to vulnerable communities. Cities are also thinking about ways to assist low-income residents with their water bills. For instance, Dallas is introducing cost savings from water bills for low-income, vulnerable residents, who tend to spend a greater proportion of their income on utilities.

Discussion

Climate urbanism explores the drivers of inequality in a climate changed city. Such research has revealed the ways in which adaptation tend to reify business-as-usual functions and reinforce hierarchical social structures rooted in historically unequal urban planning practices and their oppressive outcomes (e.g.,25). For example, redlining practices in housing and neighborhood development segregated cities and created long-lasting social and environmental inequalities47. Though climate urbanism is adept at identifying drivers of inequality, it can lack specificity about potential solutions to such problems. Our work builds on this diagnosis by exploring how cities are enacting more redistributive strategies on the ground.

Our analysis yields two main takeaways, which are introduced here and elaborated in the subsections below. First, cities are pursuing distributive equity strategies in climate adaptation although these efforts lag behind procedural equity efforts as documented elsewhere14,15. Acknowledging that procedural, distributive, and recognitional forms of injustice are linked, the planning literature has focused extensively on process and procedure related to adaptation planning, while paying less attention to what cities are trying to do on the ground to advance distributive equity (for exception, see11,41). In filling this gap, we found in our analysis that distributive equity strategies employed by large U.S. cities tend to be mostly low-hanging fruits, meaning that they tend to be easy to implement and within the sole control or jurisdiction of the cities themselves. It makes sense that cities would begin with jurisdictional specific efforts given adaptation planning has been largely left up to cities with the lack of sustained federal funding and engagement over the past decade in the U.S. Second, we see evidence that cities are beginning to rely on these strategies to catalyze more transformative action through what others have described as developing racial and gender goals in regulations, policies, and plans related to distributing more equitable outcomes and addressing inequalities resulting from land use decisions12,37. The implication of this evidence shows cities are trying to more directly tackle the drivers of climate urbanism by exploring potentially more redistributive strategies.

Our research documents the key strategies that cities are using to advance distributive equity in climate adaptation planning. These strategies suggest incremental efforts that span many different sectors with many commonalities between them. These include redistributing adaptation resources to frontline communities, a focus on basic well-being, livelihoods, and service access needs, and bridging the adaptation gap between low-income and wealthy neighborhoods. Doing so is essential for advancing sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11). Here, we highlight opportunities for redistributive action and explore opportunities cities can undertake in the future.

However, our analysis highlights that many strategies appear to be low-hanging fruits—that is, strategies that a city needs to implement to redress urban inequalities at a baseline, minimum level, rather than those that seek to proactively tackle historical and structural inequalities that will be exacerbated by climate change impacts. On the one hand, cities seek out low-hanging solutions that they potentially learn about from other cities. Cities implement these solutions to deal with immediate adaptation and adaptive capacity needs in the context of resource constraints and long-term climate uncertainties. Examples of this include building EV infrastructure in low-income communities, educational campaigns to try to reduce waste, and extending the urban tree canopy. The distributive equity actions such as the ones identified here are important to increase equity in adaptation planning and help advance climate action (SDG 13). However, few efforts focus on proactively planning for and mitigating future climate conditions. In other words, few cities consider the additional inequalities brought on by climate change, with exception of the climate displacement and housing programs as documented in Boston and Denver (see Table 1). Redistributive efforts that tackle the drivers of inequality need to be constantly revisited. Such low-hanging actions are a good start, but as with all capital-oriented solutions, questions of where, how, and who is benefiting from these solutions needs to be consistently and frequently asked. Focusing on such obvious short-term distributive strategies that are one-size-fits-all may hamper some adaptation mechanisms, such as reparations, that may more effectively address both climate vulnerabilities and past and contemporary inequality48.

Our analysis is also telling in what kinds of sectors are missing in U.S. cities’ adaptation equity actions. For example, there is little focus on education or youth resources. Given climate change impacts are likely to continue, education and youth support would be essential for advancing adaptation to improve equity both in the immediate- and long-term time horizons (e.g.,49). We found little in the plans that described media, information, or technology’s role in adaptation plans to advance distributional equity. Transportation initiatives were also missing in centering distributional equity in their approach to adaptation. These are key sectors moving forward that can help communicate and improve distributional equity in adaptation planning.

At the same time, there may be unintended consequences from the low-hanging strategies cities plan to implement, such as increased displacement, a lack of waste reduction enforcement, or a lack of benefit going to marginalized communities most vulnerable to climate impacts due to a lack of careful consideration of their specific context50. Cities are encouraged to make every effort to try to think through and limit such unintended consequences. Adaptation efforts may not reduce inequities (e.g.,51). Making strategies more relevant to the needs of specific communities in their cities could help ensure that adaptation actions can increase equity48. For example, cities should consider ways they can implement countermeasures to ensure frontline communities are able to benefit from such climate investments, such as retrofit buildings and cooling centers. Without these kinds of accompanying policy innovations, it is likely that adaptation actions will lead to greater displacement through climate gentrification52.

Furthermore, these distributive equity strategies appear across many of the cities included here. This finding may indicate that cities face similar resource and capacity constraints, which limit the opportunity space for more radical action. It also may point to the kinds of actions that cities can implement within their own jurisdictions. However, focusing on these kinds of strategies may prevent more innovative, ground-up thinking about ways to restructure urban economies to be responsive to local climate vulnerabilities37. One such unintended consequence is how adaptation can become a conflict over limited resources and capacities between communities that are at the frontlines of climate change29. Such competition prevents more collective solutions to tackle underlying structural causes (as described in this section) as well as more creative solutions that address compounding or cascading implications of climate change (i.e., across sectors, boundaries, scales, time). This lack of collective and creative problem solving can lead to further resident displacement, increased greenhouse gas emissions, investments in private industries that yield minimal social impact, or “enclaving” of risks (i.e., disconnected network of climate refugees)—all of which exacerbate climate inequality17,25.

Increasingly, scholarship has focused on the structures that maintain social inequality and climate vulnerability and how to try to address it, which has supported SDGs 11 and 13 (e.g.,10,11,14,15,24,40. To move from incremental changes to transformative redistributive actions on the ground, adaptation efforts will need to be scaled up. Climate justice frameworks (e.g.,5, 6, 7–8), broadly, and intersectional climate justice12,37, specifically, provides just such a framework to think through solutions to climate inequalities. For example, in the housing and land use space, cities might first develop explicit gender and racial equity goals across housing and land use that takes into consideration historic legacies of inequality12. To achieve these goals, cities might provide funding in the form of grants to families from disadvantaged backgrounds to address gender and racial inequalities, which can help families tackle drivers of differential vulnerability. Doing so can advance sustainable communities and cities (SDG 11) through impactful climate action (SDG 13).

Our work begins to link on the ground strategies that seek to advance distributive justice in U.S. cities with theorized pathways cities can take to tackle long standing inequalities. Doing so starts a conversation about the importance of making explicit the ways climate resilient development, especially those that are capital-oriented which climate urbanism diagnoses as drivers of inequality25, can address differential vulnerability on the ground. Our analysis makes clear cities must figure out how to scale-up from specific, incremental actions to mobilizing more transformative social change37,48,53. For example, cities could in their adaptation efforts empower local marginalized communities to manage their own resources and land thereby promoting community resilience. Doing so could foster transformative change across urban space to build more sustainable and resilient cities. A second example could be arranging reparations and ownership or access to lands for marginalized communities, which could advance place-based strategies. These specific sets of actions could help ameliorate drivers of injustice, such as the limitation of community involvement and the legacies of racial and colonial oppression. We find that cities are doing some of the work that scholars have theorized12,37,48 particularly around building community resilience—but cities have not advanced other theorized pathways, including reparations, developing a politics of care, or addressing drivers of differential vulnerability. More integration across theory, including theorized pathways for distributive justice, and what cities are doing on the ground to promote redistribution is encouraged.

There are several limitations to the current research. First, though plans were included through 2024, some of the plans are more dated than others, and given the extended timeframe there may be some variance across the plans related to distributive equity categories that are unaccounted for. Future research should consider methodologies that enable an assessment of trends over time (see for example ref. 41,). Additionally, implementation of plans and evaluation of climate actions remain two critical gaps in the field. Future research should endeavor to consider implementation and evaluation of urban adaptation plans. In this paper, we have focused on what cities are doing on the ground to advance distributive justice in their adaptation planning efforts. Other research should build on these findings in their work in other cities and in other countries. Additionally, future research should consider investigating the linkages across procedural, distributive, and recognitional justice given their theoretical connections4,11,41. Though this sample size is robust given prior research frequently focuses on single cities (e.g.,12,25), for some, 25 cities may represent a small sample size (e.g.,41). Subsequently, the generalizability of the findings may be limited, and the specific social, political, and cultural contexts of a place must be considered when drawing conclusions from this work.

In conclusion, our research shows that engagements with deeper distributive justice issues within city-level climate adaptation plans is only just emerging. Such work is essential to advance sustainable cities and climate action (including through SDGs 11 and 13). Compared to efforts that prioritize procedural equity, which has been acknowledged in the literature14,15, there are fewer actions that seek to redress distributional inequities. There remains a lack of consensus around what needs to be done in response to climate vulnerabilities and inequities. Climate urbanism approaches reviewed above offer theoretical insights to expand analysis of distributive equity in adaptation planning54,55. Yet, there remains a gap between theory and practice. To begin to bridge this gap, our paper connects climate urbanism’s diagnosis of drivers of climate inequality with climate justice approaches to guide how, where, and for whom redistributive efforts could benefit and grounds our analysis in planning practices in US cities. To address such problems, we many need to reconfigure infrastructure in urban areas to increase climate resilience50. We argue such reconfiguration needs to include an analysis of inequity, not just vulnerability, to inform climate actions that can alter infrastructure in such a way that reduces inequity. The U.S. context under the Biden Administration’s Inflation Reduction Act (2022) provided an opportunity to rethink urban climate justice given the influx of federal funding. With the recently inaugurated second Trump administration, U.S. cities will play an even more crucial role in advancing climate equity in the face of their attacks, defunding strategies, and hostility towards climate change and social equity. Without a more transformative and holistic way of thinking about and approaching distributive climate justice, there risks producing additional inequalities from climate impacts.

Research makes clear that climate change will have differential impacts on communities. City planning efforts do not yet fully consider how communities will need different strategies to face climate risks from local vulnerabilities. Acknowledging procedural, distributive, and recognitional forms of justice are linked, moving towards actions that ensure more transformative forms of distributive justice will be necessary to develop sustainable and resilient cities. In this study, we provided examples of the ways in which cities are trying to address distributive equity in their adaption planning. We find there has been movement to address distributional inequities across U.S. cities, providing some optimism for a deeper integration of justice and equity in climate adaptation planning. However, there remains a disconnect between theory and practice. Cities are only slowly bridging this gap. Our research highlights both the importance of cities as leaders in climate justice adaptation efforts and that cities across the U.S. can learn from one another in advancing distributional equity, resilience, and broader environmental sustainability goals, like SDGs 11 and 13. It remains to be seen how cities can be arenas in which these difficult questions are posed, and potential strategies can be developed and trialed especially those that tackle the underlying, structural causes of climate inequity in the first place.

Material and methods

This study investigates climate change adaptation related plans (i.e., climate resilience plans, climate action pans, and adaptation portions of general sustainability plans) for the 25 largest cities in the U.S. by population size for which plans were publicly available. Such planning documents assess actions across different municipal agencies and can be extensive. Plans generally last for many years and may not be updated unless there are specific policies governing how frequently plans will be updated. We systematically selected the 25 largest U.S. cities by metropolitan area for two main reasons. First, these cities represent ~10% of the U.S. population. Second, these are cities for which climate adaptation plans were publicly available. This case selection provides a robust sample from which to gain representative insights from what cities are doing across the U.S. (e.g., Cannon et al.11,15). This analysis helps yield necessary insights to advance SDG11 on developing sustainable cities and SDG13 on advancing climate action.

To locate city-level documents, we performed an online search of relevant planning documents for each city in three types of databases: (1) the Adaptation Clearinghouse (https://www.adaptationclearinghouse.org/), an online portal that provides resources for various stakeholders to help communities adapt to climate change; (2) individual city or municipal government websites; and (3) the specific offices of sustainability or environmental protection (if available) website for a given city. Following similar approaches of prior research, stand-alone documents are the focus of our examination to narrow the research scope for in-depth analysis (e.g., Reckien et al.56; Chu and Cannon10; Angelo, 2022). If there were multiple climate adaptation-related planning documents for a city, we selected the most recent document available at the start of data analysis at the end of 2024 or the plan that most readily and apparently addressed adaptation priorities and strategies (see, for example, Brousseau et al.41). Individual planning documents were analyzed to identify the key strategies of climate action undertaken by cities and how these actions link to distributional equity outcomes. We focus on distributional forms of inequality as prior research has focused on procedural equity in climate adaptation planning (e.g., Cannon et al.15). Plans were analyzed using diverse keyword searches to inductively code planning documents using a coding protocol (see Table 3) developed from prior research investigating equity, inclusion, and justice criteria for decision-making on climate adaptation in the 10 largest U.S. cities (see Chu and Cannon10). Search terms included the following keywords, “equit,” “vulnerab,” “equa,” “frontline,” “marginal,” “elderly,” “underserved,” “disadvantaged,” “minority,” “low-income,” “race,” “ethnicity,” “histor,” “access,” “just,” “discrimination,” “transform,” “distribution,” and “reconciliation.” Fragments are used to capture multiple meanings of the word, for example vulnerable and vulnerability. Sentences and their context were analyzed for their meaning and were coded as different dimensions of distributional equity. Building on prior environmental justice research that has found utility in describing and categorizing inequality across distributional forms (Schlosberg4), we developed coding criteria to assess what cities were doing on the ground in their adaptation planning to advance distributional equity (see Table 3). Interrater reliability of coding was achieved by two authors analyzing each plan and discussion of analysis and findings in team research meetings (see Creswell and Creswell,57). After inductive coding, plans were analyzed deductively by one author and checked by another author to identify climate adaptation actions across cities and their linkages with distributional equity outcomes (e.g., Schlosberg,58). The goal of this analysis was to identify broad categories of distributional equity as articulated in practice.

urn:contentItem:6G4M-NK13-RT5V-R37W-00000-00Environment: Carbon footprint is the same as driving from Sheffield to Sydney2025-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisCOLUMNISTSENVIRONMENTSHEFFIELDEnvironment: Carbon footprint is the same as driving from Sheffield to Sydney

Protesters gathered at Meadowhall outside the Forged Solutions factory last Tuesday morning. They were angry that Forged Solutions makes parts for F-35 fighter jets that have been bombing schools, hospitals, houses and even refugees in tents in Gaza.

More than 50,000 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli forces since October 7 and the vast majority have been women and children.

F-35 jets don’t just do enormous harm to the people they are bombing, they do enormous harm to all of us by adding dramatically to greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and exerting a massive opportunity cost. The money that has been spent on them can’t now be spent on good things like education, health, renewable energy or benefits. This was well illustrated by the Government slashing the Overseas Aid budget to pay for its massive increase in spending on weapons.

The F-35 fighter jet has a gigantic carbon footprint. For every 100 nautical miles flown, the F-35 emits approximately 2.27 tonnes of CO2. This is about the same as driving a petrol car from Sheffield to Sydney if there were a road that took you there! Emissions from war preparations are thought to make up about 5% of our global greenhouse gas total, and they must be rapidly reduced if we are to avoid climate catastrophe.

Jenny Patient spoke on behalf of Climate Justice at the demonstration and said “Public money, our taxes and our pension savings are being directed locally into arms manufacturers and our leaders are actively celebrating this as something they are proud of. But arms manufacturers can never be carbon neutral, and each job costs £200,000 to attract to our area. This money would be better spent insulating homes, investing in regenerative agriculture and in better buses”

At Brize Norton, Palestine activists broke into the RAF base and damaged two planes. This was quickly condemned by all and sundry as vandalism, but they did this to point out that flights depart daily from the base to RAF Akrotiri in Cyprus. From Cyprus, British planes collect intelligence, refuel fighter jets and transport weapons to commit genocide in Gaza. We must stop arming Israel.

Videos of the speeches and singing at the demonstration can be found at TelltheTruthSheffield.org

urn:contentItem:6G57-J4B3-S66W-64P6-00000-00Join Heat Strike because no-one should have to work in sweatshops2025-06-30T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:29:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Join Heat Strike because no-one should have to work in sweatshopsDAVE PIKE

WITH an amber heat health alert issued for parts of England, and temperatures set to top 30 degrees C in some places, the TUC is calling on employers to protect anyone working outdoors in the sun and the heat.

Climate change is turning up the dial on summer temperatures, and the question isn't if work becomes unsafe, it's when. Heat alerts like we've seen over the last few weeks are now a regular feature of British summers. The dangers of working in extreme temperatures are no longer rare - they're real, rising and completely avoidable.

It isn't just those working outside who are affected. Whether you're on a scaffold, tied to a desk in a stuffy office, driving in a van without air con, or sweating it out in an overheated warehouse, the effects of high heat aren't just uncomfortable, they're dangerous, especially for the most vulnerable.

And yet, in 2025, there's still no legal limit on how hot it can get before bosses must act. That's why the TUC is demanding a maximum working temperature in law, a safety ceiling to protect you and force bosses to make proper provision for what's now a known threat.

We already know that good employers take steps to ensure the safety of their staff, from changing working patterns to uniform requirements. Working with their people to ensure everyone can work safely.

This is why the TUC is backing the Heat Strike campaign. Heat Strike is a growing coalition of workers, unions and climate justice groups taking action when temperatures soar, through protests, walkouts and public pressure to force change. Employers must take steps to proof their workplaces and working patterns against rising temperatures.

We must also continue with climate action so that we can prevent global heating becoming more extreme, with greater costs to our lives.

Workers are entitled to remain away from the workplace if - in their opinion - prevailing circumstances represent a real risk of "serious and imminent" danger which they could not be expected to avert.

So don't sweat it alone. Join your union. Talk with your colleagues and get involved in Heat Strike. Because climate change isn't just an environmental issue, it's a workplace one. And if ministers and bosses won't act, we will.

Dave Pike is regional secretary of the TUC
